Graphical abstract In the present study, UiO-66(Ce) metal-organic framework (MOF) was synthesized by solvothermal method and thoroughly characterized by powder X-ray diffraction (XRD), Fourier-transform infrared (FT-IR), Raman, UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectra (UV-DRS) and scanning electron microscope (SEM) techniques to confirm its formation . The catalytic performance of UiO-66(Ce) was studied in the aerobic oxidation of benzyl amines to their respective imines with high selectivity. Among the various catalysts screened for the aerobic oxidation of benzyl amine (1) to its respective imine (3), UiO-66(Ce) exhibited the highest activity and is due to its high oxophilicity as well as high surface area. The reaction was heterogeneous as shown by hot-filtration test and the activity of the solid is retained up to four reuses. A series of control experiments indicated that the reaction operates through radical mechanism. Substrate scope studies showed that UiO-66(Ce) solid is efficient in promoting the oxidation of benzyl amines and no reaction occurred for aniline and n-butylamine. keywords Aerobic oxidation Benzyl amine Heterogeneous catalysis Metal-organic framework Mesoporous solids 1 Introduction A convenient strategy for the selective synthesis of imines from amines is often achieved via oxidation reaction in the presence of an oxidizing agent and is also considered as a model reaction in organic transformations to rank various catalytic systems [1]. In addition, large numbers of fine chemicals, biologically active molecules and drugs have been prepared from imines as raw materials [2–4]. Conventionally, one of the easiest methods for the synthesis of imines is through the condensation of amines with aldehydes or ketones [5]. On the other hand, a more fascinating strategy for the synthesis of imines is by the direct oxidation of amines with a suitable catalyst and oxidant. Some of the commonly used precious transition metals for the oxidation of amines to imines are palladium [6], ruthenium [7], gold [8] and vanadium [9]. The limited availability of these metals and their high cost forces to develop a process with a cheap transition metal that can show comparable activity to these precious metals. Furthermore, 2-iodoxybenzoic acid and N-tert-butylphenylsulfinimidoyl chloride were used as oxidants for this transformation [10,11] but, these oxidants are not environmentally benign and it is a tedious process to separate them from the reaction mixture. Thus, a direct, selective oxidation of amines to imines using molecular oxygen as an oxidant may be an ideal process from the sustainability point of view, but it certainly requires an efficient catalyst to promote this transformation. MOFs are organic-inorganic hybrid porous solids whose crystalline frameworks are constituted by metal ions/clusters with polytopic organic linkers through covalent linkage [12–14]. In the last two decades, MOFs have been widely used in large numbers of applications mainly due to their unique and exciting properties like high surface area, tunable pore size, well arranged crystal patterns and high chemical/structural diversity [15,16]. Compared to other porous solids, MOFs provide high synthetic flexibility and modularity in their crystalline frameworks, thus effectively used in diverse fields such as gas separation [17], gas storage [18], drug delivery [19], chemical sensing [20], catalysis [21,22], proton conduction [23], and among others. Of importance, MOFs have also been used as heterogeneous solid catalysts for gas phase reactions [24] thus clearly illustrating their thermal stability. Among the various reactions that have been reported using MOFs as solid catalysts [25–28], aerobic oxidation is one of the frequently studied reactions [29–35] and is due to the well defined active sites like coordinatively unsaturated metal sites behaving as Lewis acid sites [36], metal nanoparticles encapsulated inside MOFs that are responsible for promoting oxidation of various substrates. Hence, this field is still developing to achieve high selectivity of the oxidized products at high conversion. One of the limitations of certain MOFs in catalysis is their low thermal/chemical stability leading to the collapse of the framework during the course of the reaction. This issue was addressed by developing a robust and highly stable UiO-66 (UiO: University of Oslo) MOFs and their characterization data clearly proved that they exhibit high chemical and thermal stabilities compared to other MOFs [37]. UiO-66(Zr) MOFs were often synthesized by the chemical reaction between Zr4+ as metal ions and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (BDC) as organic linkers under solvothermal method leading to the formation of three-dimensional frameworks having the structural formula of [Zr6O4(OH)4(BDC)6] with face centered cubic arrangement [38,39]. The structure of UiO-66(Zr) is constituted by large octahedral (0.9 nm) and small tetrahedral (0.7 nm) cages and they can be accessed through triangular windows of about 0.6 nm. Furthermore, BET surface area of UiO-66(Zr) was found to be 1187 m2/g [37]. Due to the successful formation of UiO-66(Zr) with tetra-positive metal ions, analogous MOFs with UiO-66 based frameworks were subsequently synthesized with wide range of transition metal ions like Hf(IV) [40], Ti(IV) [41], U(IV) [42], Th(IV) [43] and Ce(IV) [44] with higher physicochemical stability. In one of the seminal contributions, UiO-66(Ce) was prepared by the chemical reaction between cerium(IV) ammonium nitrate (CAN) as the metal ion source and BDC as organic linker under solvothermal method with the resemblance of UiO-66(Zr) architecture [44]. The structural arrangements of UiO-66(Ce) revealed that the clusters [Ce6O4(OH)4]12+ are connected by six BDC ligands in a cubic close-packed fashion with the chemical formula Ce6O4(OH)4(BDC)6 [44]. The BET surface area of UiO-66(Ce) was measured to be 1272 m2/g. Although considerable progress has been made in the preparation of UiO-66(Ce) related solids, the catalytic performance of these solids is limited to few reactions [44–50]. Oxidation of 1 to 3 often accompanies with other possible products like benzaldehyde (2), benzaldoxime, benzonitrile and N-benzoylbenzyl amine (4). Hence, selective oxidation of 1 to 3 is a challenging reaction. This transformation has been effected by series of MOF-based catalysts that include NHPI/Fe(BTC) (NHPI: N-hydroxyphthalimide; BTC: 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate), [51] Mn/Co-MOF [52], Pd-Au@Mn(II)-MOF [53], Au@UiO-66 [54] and Cu3(BTC)2 [55]. On the other hand, selective oxidation of 1 to 3 was also reported with wide range of catalysts under photocatalytic conditions [56–62]. In the present work, UiO-66(Ce) is reported as a highly efficient heterogeneous solid promoting the aerobic oxidation of 1 with relatively high activity compared to other analogous catalysts under identical conditions. Some of the merits of this work compared to other reports are solvent-free procedure, no requirement of radical initiator, readily available cost-effective transition metal and easy preparation of MOF catalyst. Furthermore, this work is also expected to stimulate further dimensions of oxidation reactions since the number of reports with this solid is limited compared to UiO-66(Zr). 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials The various raw materials for the preparation of MOFs including UiO-66(Ce) and various benzyl amine derivatives were purchased from Sigma Aldrich and used as received with no additional purification procedures unless otherwise mentioned. The purities of these materials were CAN (>99.99 %), ZrOCl2.8H2O (>99 %), Cr(NO3)3.9H2O (99 %), FeCl3.6H2O (98 %), Co(NO3)2.6H2O (97 %), Zn(NO3)2.6H2O (98 %), CeO2 nanoparticles (99.99 %; Product number 544841), AIBN (98 %), TEMPO (98 %), BDC (98 %), 2-methylimidazole (98 %), N, N’-dimethylformamide (DMF) (99.9 %), methanol (99.5 %), 1 (98 %), 4-methylbenzyl amine (97 %), 4-chlorobenzyl amine (98 %), 4-fluorobenzyl amine (97 %), 3,4-dichlorobenzyl amine (95 %), 4-(trifluoromethyl)benzyl amine (97 %), furfuryl amine (99 %), picolyl amine (99 %), n-butylamine (99 %), aniline (99 %) and dihydroindole (97 %). 2.2 Instrumentations Powder XRD patterns were collected using Philips X’Pert diffractometer with CuKα radiation (λ = 1.5417 Å) in the refraction mode. FT-IR spectra were recorded in the region of 400-4000 cm−1 with the resolution of 2 cm−1 using a Bruker tensor 27 series FT-IR spectrometer. SEM images were measured from Hitachi S-3000H scanning electron microscope. UV-DRS were recorded by Shimadzu UV-2700; ISR-2600 plus instrument in the range between 200–800 nm and the samples were dispersed on the surface of BaSO4. Conversion and selectivity data were determined by gas chromatography (GC) with Agilent 7820 A model using nitrogen as a carrier gas. Further, GC coupled with mass spectrometry (GC–MS) of 5890 B series was used to confirm the products. 2.3 Synthesis of UiO-66(Ce) UiO-66(Ce) solids were prepared by following a procedure reported elsewhere [44]. Initially, BDC (35.4 mg) was placed in a reaction tube followed by the addition of DMF (1.2 mL) containing aqueous solution of CAN (400 μL, 0.5333 M). The reaction tube was sealed and placed on a preheated oil bath at 100 °C and allowed to stir for 15 min. Then, yellow precipitate was recovered by centrifuging the mother liquor and washed thoroughly two times with DMF (2 mL) to remove free BDC from the solid. Later, the solid was washed with methanol (2 mL), centrifuged and this process was repeated for four times to remove the adsorbed DMF from the material. Finally, the obtained solid was dried at 80 °C in air to obtain pure and crystalline solid. A detailed procedure for the preparation of MIL-101(Cr), MIL-101(Fe), ZIF-8, ZIF-67 and UiO-66 MOFs is given in Supporting Information. These solids were characterized by powder XRD and IR methods to ascertain their formation (Figures S1-S9). 2.4 General procedure for the aerobic oxidation of 1 In a typical reaction, a dried 25 mL round bottom flask was charged with UiO-66(Ce) (50 mg) solid followed by adding 1 (0.5 mL). This reaction mixture was sealed with a silicon septum. Later, this slurry was placed on a preheated oil bath maintained at 120 °C. This heterogeneous reaction mixture was constantly purged with high pure molecular oxygen (99.99 %) through a balloon. This reaction mixture was stirred for the time intervals shown in Table 1. A known amount of aliquot (25 μL) was taken, diluted with acetonitrile (0.5 mL) and was filtered using a syringe filter. This sample was analyzed by GC (operation conditions: HP-5 capillary column, oven temperature 50–300 °C at ramp rate 10 °C/min and inlet temperature of 250 °C) to determine conversion and selectivity (Eqs. 1 and 2) using internal standard method. After the required time, the reaction was stopped, cooled to room temperature. Later, the mixture was diluted with acetonitrile (3 mL) and filtered to recover the solid for further studies. The final reaction mixture was analyzed by GC to determine its conversion, selectivity and products were confirmed by GC–MS (Figures S10-S31) with identical conditions used for GC. The analysis of the reaction mixture indicated the existence of products 2, 3, 4. The mass balances of the reactions were more than 98 %. Reusability experiments were performed by using the recovered solid with the fresh 1 by following the above described procedure. Eq.1 Conversion of 1 (%) = moles of 1 reacted/initial moles of 1 Eq.2 Selectivity of 3 (%) = moles of 3 formed/total moles of 2, 3 and 4 Furthermore, the above procedure was also followed for some control experiments in the presence of TEMPO (11 mg) and AIBN (12 mg) as radical initiators to reveal the nature of active sites with similar moles to Ce content in UiO-66(Ce). Similarly, other control experiments with homogeneous CAN (39 mg), BDC (40 mg) and heterogeneous n-CeO2 (12 mg) catalysts were also performed under identical conditions with identical cerium/linker loading as in the case of UiO-66(Ce). 3 Results and discussion UiO-66(Ce) was obtained by following the recipe of an earlier method [44] and characterized by powder XRD, UV-DRS, FT-IR, Raman spectroscopy and SEM analyses to confirm the formation of MOF material and to reveal its morphology. Powder XRD pattern of the fresh UiO-66(Ce) solid is presented in Fig. 1 and is closely related to the XRD pattern of UiO-66(Zr) [63]. The XRD pattern of UiO-66(Ce) clearly shows sharp reflections around 2θ values of 7.3°, 8.2°, 11.6°, 13.6°, 14.3° corresponding to (111), (200), (220), (311) and (222) planes, respectively. Furthermore, these reflections were shifted to lower 2θ values than to UiO-66(Zr) and is due to the higher radii of Ce4+ (0.97 Å) compared to Zr4+ (0.84 Å) (Figure S32). These XRD patterns, peak intensities and peak positions clearly indicate the formation of a highly crystalline solid and on the other hand, they are in close agreement with the reported diffraction patterns [44,64]. Further, it is assumed that the crystal structure of UiO-66(Ce) is identical to the reported solid [44]. FT-IR spectra of UiO-66(Ce) are shown in Fig. 2 and they are identical with the reported data [44]. Briefly, the asymmetric (1560 cm−1) and symmetric (1384 cm−1) stretching frequencies of the carboxylate groups are clearly present in the UiO-66(Ce) solid. Furthermore, the stretching vibration of Ce-O bond in CeO2 was observed at 447 cm−1, but it appears at 521 cm−1 in UiO-66(Ce) and this huge shift is due to the coordination of BDC linkers with Ce4+ ions. These results are also in good agreement with earlier report [65]. Further, UV-DRS analysis of UiO-66(Ce) and BDC were also recorded and the results are shown in Fig. 3 . The absorption edge arising due to Ce4+ is seen at around 400 nm which matches with an earlier report [66]. On the other hand, the absorption bands appeared at 250 and 320 nm in the UV region correspond to the charge transfer transition from BDC of O2−(2 P) to Ce4+ of (4f) orbital [67]. The Raman spectra of UiO-66(Ce) and BDC linker are shown in Fig. 4 . UiO-66(Ce) solid shows a prominent band at around 460 cm−1 which is assigned to Ce4+ vibrational mode [68] in the framework of UiO-66(Ce). The vibrational bands of carboxylate groups in BDC are also observed in UiO-66(Ce) with slight shifts thus confirming the coordination of BDC with Ce4+. Furthermore, the vibrational band of Ce-O is observed with higher intensity in UiO-66(Ce) compared to other vibrational bands corresponding to BDC. Fig. 5 shows the SEM image of the fresh UiO-66(Ce) and it indicates that the morphology of particles is mostly present as spherical particles with agglomeration. Further SEM images of UiO-66(Ce) were also reported with other morphologies like spherical [44,70] and deformed octahedral [71] with agglomerations. These results clearly indicate that the morphology of UiO-66(Ce) in this work closely agrees with previous report [44]. After ascertaining the structural integrity of UiO-66(Ce), the catalytic performance of UiO-66(Ce) was examined in the aerobic oxidation of 1 and the reaction was optimized in terms of reaction temperature, catalyst loading and effect of oxidant. Initially, a blank control experiment without catalyst provided 25 % conversion of 1 with complete selectivity to 3 at 120 °C after 12 h. The precursors of UiO-66(Ce) like CAN and BDC resulted in 42 and 26 % conversions, respectively at 120 °C after 12 h. Under identical conditions, UiO-66(Ce) afforded 97 % conversion of 1 with 95 % selectivity to 3. These results clearly prove the superior activity of UiO-66(Ce) in heterogeneous medium than its precursors under homogeneous medium. The enhanced activity of UiO-66(Ce) may be due to its high surface area, well-defined active sites (Ce4+) in highly ordered MOF crystallites with facile accessibility of 1. Furthermore, the higher activity of UiO-66(Ce) is due to the presence of highly accessible Ce4+ sites within the MOF framework. Fig. 6 shows the time conversion plot for the aerobic oxidation of 1 and selectivity to 3 under these reaction conditions. On the other hand, the catalytic behavior of UiO-66(Ce) was dropped to 75 and 38 % conversions when the reaction temperature decreased to 100 and 80 °C respectively. However, the selectivity of 3 was almost identical to all reaction temperatures. These catalytic data are displayed in Fig. 7 . Similarly, the activity of UiO-66(Ce) was decreased to 71 and 30 % conversions of 1 while lowering the catalyst loading to 25 and 5 mg, respectively at 120 °C after 12 h. In addition, no change in the selectivity to 3 was observed with these catalyst loadings. These results clearly indicate that the notable decrease in the activity upon reducing catalyst dosage is obviously due to the reduction in the population of active sites in the reaction medium (Fig. 8 ). In order to establish the role of oxidant, two control experiments were performed under air and nitrogen atmospheres and the observed catalytic data are plotted in Fig. 9 . These results clearly suggest that the reaction of 1 to 3 proceeds with faster rate under molecular oxygen while it decreased with air and nitrogen atmospheres under similar experimental parameters. In contrast, the reaction of 1 to 3 has also been reported with Cu(I) [72], Pt/PCN-777 [56], ZnIn2S4 [73], Ni/CdS [74], and CeO2 [75] under air or nitrogen atmospheres with high conversion of 1. Therefore, the conversion of 1 is influenced by the nature of catalyst, oxidant, substrate/catalyst ratio and reaction mode like thermal/photochemical conditions. The active site in UiO-66(Ce) was ascertained by conducting a control experiment with n-CeO2 and the results are shown in Table 1 . The conversion of 1 was 34 % with n-CeO2 which is three-fold lower than the activity of UiO-66(Ce). These results indicate that Ce4+ is acting as active sites in both solids, but the lower activity of n-CeO2 is due to its different coordination environment and relatively lower numbers of well defined active sites. Furthermore, the activity of an analogous solid, UiO-66(Zr) was tested for the aerobic oxidation of 1 under similar experimental conditions. The observed catalytic data indicate that the activity of UiO-66(Ce) is much superior than UiO-66(Zr) and is ascribed due to the lower oxophilicity of Zr4+ (0.8) than Ce4+ (0.9). In order to rationalize the nature of reaction pathway, series of control experiments were performed with radical initiators like AIBN and TEMPO. These two radical initiators are widely used in organic synthesis for radical mediated reactions. The use of TEMPO and AIBN as radical initiators afforded 32 and 58 % conversions of 1, respectively with around 92 % selectivity to 3 under similar experimental conditions. These catalytic results with radical initiators indirectly suggest that the reaction proceeds with UiO-66(Ce) via radical mechanism. These radical initiators initiate the oxidation reaction by producing the first radical which upon reaction with molecular oxygen propagates the radical chain mechanism leading to moderate conversion of 1. On the other hand, the activity of UiO-66(Ce) is much higher than these radical initiators and this significant difference in the activity is due to the retainment of active catalytic sites in the solid than with radical initiators. Furthermore, the activity of UiO-66(Ce) was compared with series of catalysts with different textural properties and oxidation states of the transition metals within the MOF. The observed catalytic data are plotted in Fig. 10 . These results suggest that ZIF-8, Fe(BTC) and UiO-66(Zr) exhibited lower activity while ZIF-67 showed moderate activity in the conversion of 1 to 3 under the optimized reaction conditions. In contrast, MIL-101(Fe), MIL-101(Cr) and Cu3(BTC)2 afforded significantly higher activity than the above mentioned catalysts. The activity of the last three solids is not very far from the activity of UiO-66(Ce). The oxophilicity values [76] of Zn, Fe, Zr, Co, Cr, Cu and Ce are 0.2, 0.4, 0.8, 0.4, 0.6, 0.2 and 0.9 respectively. One of the factors responsible for the superior activity of UiO-66(Ce) among the tested catalysts is due to its high oxophilicity value. On the other hand, the comparable activity of MIL-101(Fe), MIL-101(Cr) and Cu3(BTC)2 is due to their effective generation of primary radicals along with their high surface area. Furthermore, the significant difference in the activity between ZIF-8 and ZIF-67 may be due to the nature of metal ion since Co-based catalysts are preferred solids for promoting oxidation reactions. [77] After demonstrating the superior activity of UiO-66(Ce) in the aerobic oxidation of 1, we were interested to examine the stability of catalyst by performing hot filtration and reusability tests. Fig. 6 shows the time conversion plots with and without UiO-66(Ce) for the aerobic oxidation of 1 at 120 °C and the selectivity of 3. The solid catalyst was filtered after 1 h at the reaction temperature and the reaction progress in the absence of solid was also monitored. The catalytic data indicate that the reaction rate is significantly decreased upon removal of UiO-66(Ce), thus implying the requirement of catalyst to promote this oxidation reaction. However, the conversion of 1 was slightly increased after removal of the catalyst (Fig. 6b) and this may be due to the contribution of blank experiment (Fig. 6c). In order to support this hypothesis, the reaction mixture was analyzed by ICP analysis and observing 1 ppm of Ce in the solution. Hence, the reaction proceeds via heterogeneous fashion and contribution of leached species are almost negligible. Furthermore, the catalyst was recycled four times with no significant decay in its activity and selectivity (Fig. 11 ), while the minor decrease observed in the activity in each cycle is due to the loss of solid catalyst during recovery and washing processes. These reusability data was further supported by comparing the powder XRD patterns between the fresh and the recovered, reused UiO-66(Ce) solids. The crystallinity, peak positions and peak intensities of two times reused UiO-66(Ce) solids showed identical XRD patterns to the fresh solid and hence, the structural integrity of UiO-66(Ce) is retained during the oxidation reaction. Also, SEM images of fresh and two times reused UiO-66(Ce) solids showed some changes in the morphology during the reuses (Fig. 5). These changes in the morphology of the reused solid may be due to the mechanical stress created during the reaction time. The scope of UiO-66(Ce) was further tested with substituted benzyl amines under the optimized reaction conditions. 4-Methylbenzyl amine afforded 83 % conversion with 92 % selectivity of the desired product at 120 °C after 12 h (entry 1, Table 2). Further, 4-chloro and 4-fluorobenzyl amines exhibited 85 % and 89 % conversions, respectively under identical reaction conditions (entries 2-3, Table 2). Also, 3,4-dichlorobenzyl amine was oxidized to its respective imine at 79 % conversion at 120 °C after 12 h (entry 4, Table 2). This lower conversion is ascribed due to the bulky halogens that may impose diffusion limitations to reach the active sites. Similarly, 4-trifluoromethylbenzyl amine gave 88 % conversion with 87 % selectivity to its corresponding imine under similar conditions (entry 5, Table 2). Aromatic amines containing heteroatoms were also oxidized to their respective imines in 94 % conversions under identical conditions (entries 6-7, Table 2). These catalytic data indicate that the conversion of benzyl amine derivatives is not solely determined by electronic nature of the substituents while other factors like nature of active site, reaction mechanism, molecular dimensions of substrates and their diffusion limitations to reach active sites are also playing a crucial role. Finally, efforts to oxidize n-butylamine, aniline and dihydroindole were not successful due to the lack of benzylic positions both at 80 and 120 °C (entries 8-10, Table 2). Therefore, this catalyst is highly suitable for the aerobic oxidation of amines bearing benzylic positions . 4 Conclusions In summary, this work has shown the successful synthesis of UiO-66(Ce) by solvothermal method and its characterization by series of techniques like XRD, FT-IR, Raman, UV-DRS and SEM images confirm structural integrity, crystalline nature and morphology. The catalytic performance of UiO-66(Ce) was evaluated in the aerobic oxidation of 1 with high conversion and selectivity to 3. Among the various catalysts screened for the aerobic oxidation of 1, UiO-66(Ce) exhibited the superior activity. This enhanced activity is ascribed due to its high oxophilicity and surface area. The reaction was proven to be heterogeneous and catalyst was reused for four recycles. Series of control experiments have supported the possible reaction pathway through radical intermediates. Although this solid catalyst was able to oxidize benzyl amine derivatives with high conversion and selectivity, efforts to oxidize aniline and n-butylamine were failed. coredata.dc:description: In the present study, UiO-66(Ce) metal-organic framework (MOF) was synthesized by solvothermal method and thoroughly characterized by powder X-ray diffraction (XRD), Fourier-transform infrared (FT-IR), Raman, UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectra (UV-DRS) and scanning electron microscope (SEM) techniques to confirm its formation . The catalytic performance of UiO-66(Ce) was studied in the aerobic oxidation of benzyl amines to their respective imines with high selectivity. Among the various catalysts screened for the aerobic oxidation of benzyl amine (1) to its respective imine (3), UiO-66(Ce) exhibited the highest activity and is due to its high oxophilicity as well as high surface area. The reaction was heterogeneous as shown by hot-filtration test and the activity of the solid is retained up to four reuses. A series of control experiments indicated that the reaction operates through radical mechanism. Substrate scope studies showed that UiO-66(Ce) solid is efficient in promoting the oxidation of benzyl amines and no reaction occurred for aniline and n-butylamine.
coredata.dc:title: UiO-66(Ce) metal-organic framework as a highly active and selective catalyst for the aerobic oxidation of benzyl amines
